content:
This is the current output of lake build and lake test, respectively:

-- ⣷ [1886/5360] Running Mathlib.RingTheory.EuclideanDomain (+ 16 more)
(lake build output)

-- ⣟ [2663/2673] Running MathlibTest.matrix (+ 7 more)
(lake test output)

Note that the word "Running" is used in both cases: when building a module and when running a test.

When invoking both lake build and lake test from a shell script, it is currently not possible to easily distinguish between build steps and test execution based on the output alone.

Is there any technical reason why the term "Building" isn’t used in the lake build case: something that would be more in line with conventions in other languages?

Naively, I would expect the output to look like this:

-- % lake build
-- ⣷ [1886/5360] Building Mathlib.RingTheory.EuclideanDomain (+ 16 more)
-- % lake test
-- ⣟ [2663/2673] Running MathlibTest.matrix (+ 7 more)
